Description: Mould-made amulet in glazed composition, in the shape of a one-sided right wedjat-eye; tubular loop for suspension above, pierced lengthwise; some remains of pale greenish turquoise glaze; detailing of eye and brow incised; very worn glaze; incisions filled with brown earth; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

In addition to scarabs which were mass-produced especially for export, wedjat eyes, mainly in glazed composition but also in hard stone, form the main type of amulets found at Naukratis. Amulet with universal power of protection (Germond 2005, 25), the wedjat eye, simple or multiple, is one of the most common amulet on settlements of the Late Period (Masson forthcoming). Quite close parallels from Naukratis: Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H2009.4; London, Petrie Museum UC52356. Germond, P. 2005, Le monde symbolique des amulettes égyptiennes de la collection Jacques-Édouard Berger, Milan. Masson, A. forthcoming, Le quartier des prêtres sur la rive est du Lac Sacré à Karnak.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.299) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: World Museum, Liverpool
